description:
'''Country music''', also known as '''country and western''' or simply '''country''', is a [[popular music|music genre]], known for its [[ballad]]s and dance tunes, identifiable by both folk lyrics and harmonies accompanied by [[banjo]]s, [[fiddle]]s, [[harmonica]]s, and many types of [[guitar]]; either [[acoustic guitar|acoustic]], [[electric guitar|electric]], [[steel guitar|steel]], or [[resonator guitar|resonator]] guitars.

Country music likely originated in the [[Southern United States]], and spread throughout the Piedmont area of United States, from Louisiana along the [[Appalachian Mountains]] to New York. The music is believed to be derived from [[British folk music]], brought to the United States during early waves of immigration. Rooted in [[American folk music]], such as [[old-time music|old-time]] and Southern [[Appalachian music]], many other traditions – particularly [[African-American music|African-American]] traditional folk songs and hymns – blended to become the genre known as country music. Once called ''[[hillbilly music]],'' the term country music was popularized in the 1940s.

[[Music of Mexico|Mexican]], [[Music of Ireland|Irish]], and [[Music of Hawaii|Hawaiian music]], have had a formative influence on the genre, as well as [[Jazz scale#Blues scale|blues modes]] from [[blues music]], which have shaped the evolution of country music.

Country music has remained an integral part of the [[American music|American music scene]], with a recent revitalization in interest since the early 2020s. In 2023, 45% of Americans reported listening to country music, an uptick in the genre's popularity.
